St. Helens, 30th May, 1858.

Thanks for your congratulations to my birthday; the same to Edwards, coming in a few days, may they all be fulfilled! Thanks for Georgies dress, I am glad you did not make it up. You have so much sewing to do & Georgie does not need it full yet. — How Georges Cattle are doing? George thinks they will do; patience & time; we are expected to eat our bread with the sweat on our brow!

I was sorry to see in the last Observer that Mr. Charles Stirling died, his poor young wife! Yesterday I had a long letter from Miss Tilly, she has been 7 weeks ill with Colonial fever, the poor thing. She is looking for a situation as Governess, I will ask her to come to us, if she has no place yet, I always liked her. I am always suffering, otherwise we are so happy, our little darling gives us so much pleasure, he could not be better, & always so happy the dear Child & so well; he moves the chairs about now & takes great pleasure in pictures & books; he pulls the bellrope when he gets near it & says kli-li-li,
June 1st. - A busy week, Cattle mustering, 9 men in the kitchen. I take Georgie out in the morning & let him see them ride away, which is a great pleasure for him.
Poor little man fell out of his bed this morning, it gave me a great fright, but he does not seem to have hurt himself. [...]
